required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on November 19, 2021
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Feedback, Motor Sequence Learning, and Brain Connectivity
clinical_study.official_title: Effects of Feedback on Learning of a Motor Sequence Task and Resting State Connectivity

brief_summary.textblock: Feedback delivered during motor practice can help promote motor skill learning, enhance confidence, and alter brain connectivity. However, the optimal way to provide feedback to promote learning, confidence and brain connectivity is unknown. This project will study how the feedback that is provided during practice of a movement skill can help people learn and build confidence and whether these correspond to changes in brain function. The investigators will measure motor skill performance, confidence, and resting state brain connectivity before and after a session of motor practice.

detailed_description.textblock: Positive social comparative feedback, which indicate to the learner that they are performing above average, is one way to enhance a learner's expectancies about future performance. Expectancies include the learners' perceived competence about their ability to perform the task, expectations about task outcome (success or failure), and predictions of extrinsic reward or positive experiences related to performance. Positive feedback during motor practice enhances expectancies, which is hypothesized to be rewarding to the learner, leading to better skill performance and learning. Reward is a powerful shaper of behavior. However, while social comparative feedback supports motor skill learning, it is unclear whether positive social comparative feedback induces a response in the dopamine reward network. Therefore, the purpose of this study is to determine the effects of social comparative feedback during motor practice on the functional connectivity of the reward neural network. The study aims to recruit 40 participants who will be randomized into 1 of 2 feedback groups (performance feedback or performance plus positive feedback). Participants will practice a motor sequence task on a single day and then return for retention performance testing about 24 hours later. Measures of brain function and brain structure will be collected before and after practice on day 1. Changes in performance (response time to complete a sequence) and self-efficacy will be measured from baseline to 24 hours later at retention. Changes in brain functional connectivity over practice on day 1 will be assessed in the reward network and the motor network.

primary_outcome.time_frame: Change from baseline to retention at 24 hours
Change from baseline to retention at 24 hours
primary_outcome.description: Self-reported confidence in ability to complete a sequence in a given time on a scale of 0 to 10 with a 10 equating to higher confidence

primary_outcome.time_frame: Change from baseline to immediately after practice
primary_outcome.description: Resting state connectivity between pairs of brain regions

secondary_outcome.time_frame: Change from baseline to retention at 24 hours
secondary_outcome.description: Average speed to capture a target within a sequence

secondary_outcome.time_frame: Change from baseline to retention at 24 hours
secondary_outcome.description: Total distance traveled to complete one sequence

secondary_outcome.time_frame: Change from baseline to retention at 24 hours
secondary_outcome.description: Mean time to peak velocity for movement to a target within a sequence

secondary_outcome.time_frame: Change from baseline to retention at 24 hours
secondary_outcome.description: Mean score on the Perceived Competence subscale of the Intrinsic Motivation Inventory where each item ranges from 0 to 7 with a higher value equating to higher competence

secondary_outcome.time_frame: Change from baseline to retention at 24 hours
secondary_outcome.description: Mean score on the Interest/Enjoyment subscale of the Intrinsic Motivation Inventory where each item ranges from 0 to 7 with a higher value equating to higher enjoyment

secondary_outcome.time_frame: Change from baseline to retention at 24 hours
secondary_outcome.description: Total score for general positive affect on the Positive and Negative Affect Scale with a range from 10 to 50 with higher scores equating to higher positive affect

secondary_outcome.time_frame: Change from baseline to immediately after practice
secondary_outcome.description: Average speed to capture a target within a sequence

secondary_outcome.description: Total distance traveled to complete one sequence

secondary_outcome.description: Mean score on the Perceived Competence subscale of the Intrinsic Motivation Inventory where each item ranges from 0 to 7 with a higher value equating to higher competence

Change from baseline to immediately after practice
secondary_outcome.description: Self-reported confidence in ability to complete a sequence in a given time on a scale of 0 to 10 with a 10 equating to higher confidence
Structural integrity of white matter pathways in the brain

arm_group.description: Practice of a joystick based motor sequence task. Participants receive feedback on their response time to complete the trials in the practice block.
Practice of a joystick based motor sequence task. Participants receive feedback on their response time to complete the trials in the practice block plus positive social comparative feedback.

intervention.description: Participants will be seated at a laptop with the right hand on a standard joystick. The movement of the joystick will move a cursor on the computer screen. Targets will appear on the laptop screen as a circle in one of twelve spatially distinct locations. The learner must move the joystick "cursor" to inside the target before the next target will appear.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Age 18 to 40 years
- Right-hand dominant
Exclusion Criteria:
- Medical diagnosis or medication that affects dopamine (e.g. dopamine reuptake inhibitors)
- Musculoskeletal issues that limit upper extremity movement
- Contraindications for magnetic resonance imaging (MRI)

patient_data.ipd_description: De-identified data will be made available per reasonable request to the principal investigator 1 year after study completion.
